title: Apple Vision Pro 2 Sells Out Within Hours of Launch
introText: Apple's second-generation mixed reality headset has shattered sales records, selling out within hours of its launch. The Vision Pro 2 addresses many criticisms of the original model with improved comfort, extended battery life, and a significantly lower price point.

content.content: Apple Vision Pro 2 launches to unprecedented demand

Apple Stores worldwide saw lines stretching around blocks as eager customers awaited the Vision Pro 2 launch. Online orders sold out in under two hours, with shipping estimates quickly extending to February 2026. Apple has not disclosed specific sales figures but confirmed demand 'significantly exceeded' expectations.

The company has ramped up production at its assembly partners, but supply constraints are expected to persist through the holiday season. Secondary market prices have already surged well above retail.

The Vision Pro 2 weighs 30% less than its predecessor and features a redesigned headband that distributes weight more evenly. Battery life has doubled to 4 hours, addressing a major complaint about the original model.

Perhaps most significantly, Apple has reduced the price from $3,499 to $2,499, making the device more accessible to mainstream consumers. The company achieved cost savings through manufacturing efficiencies and component improvements.

The display system has been upgraded with 8K resolution per eye and an expanded field of view. New 'immersive environments' allow users to work or relax in photorealistic virtual settings, from mountain retreats to futuristic workspaces.

Hand tracking has been refined for more precise interactions, and eye tracking enables intuitive navigation without controllers. Third-party app developers have embraced the platform, with over 5,000 spatial apps now available.

The launch puts pressure on Meta, whose Quest 3 has dominated the VR market. While Meta's headset remains more affordable, the Vision Pro 2 offers capabilities that justify its premium for many users.

Analysts predict the spatial computing market will grow rapidly as Apple's entry legitimizes the category. Enterprise applications, from design visualization to remote collaboration, are expected to drive adoption beyond consumer gaming and entertainment.
